name: Collaborative Setup and Personalization
description: This use case describes the joint onboarding process where older adults with diverse attitudes towards technology and privacy, together with their caregivers, configure ALFRED to suit individual needs. It enables personalization of health monitoring, social interaction preferences, and system accessibility while respecting privacy concerns.
scenario:
Elena Rivera, ever curious and eager to embrace new technology, sat comfortably in her urban apartment as Sarah Thompson, her informal caregiver, walked her through the initial setup of the ALFRED system. Elena was excited to configure the voice assistant, asking questions about how she could push herself with more challenging exercises and how ALFRED would suggest daily to-do lists tailored to her lifestyle. She openly shared her health data, gladly agreeing to wear the sleek sensors that ALFRED supported, confident that this would help her maintain independence and stay connected with her family.

Meanwhile, Olivia, who lived alone in a quieter suburban neighborhood and had a deep mistrust of technology, was less enthusiastic. When Sarah visited Olivia to assist with her ALFRED setup, Olivia insisted on limiting notifications to only the most essential ones, especially blocking alerts about strenuous exercises. She firmly rejected video check-ins, preferring privacy and offline communication. Olivia was adamant that no health data be shared with anyone, even her caregiver Sarah, and insisted that all messages to and from ALFRED remain formal and restrained. Sarah found it challenging to respect Olivia’s cautious stance while trying to ensure her safety and well-being. She patiently navigated Olivia’s privacy settings, toggling off many features Elena had embraced, and reassured Olivia that the system would not intrude beyond her preferences.

Sarah, balancing these very different needs, found herself toggling between the two women’s profiles on her caregiver console, appreciating ALFRED’s flexibility but also feeling the strain of managing such contrasting expectations. She encouraged Elena’s enthusiasm by enabling motivational exercise reminders and social event suggestions, while for Olivia, she carefully configured ALFRED to minimize interruptions and preserve strict data privacy. This delicate personalization process underscored for Sarah the importance of a system that could serve both the tech-curious and the privacy-wary without compromising either’s autonomy. By the end of their sessions, Elena was already planning to challenge herself with ALFRED’s fitness games, while Olivia felt cautiously reassured that her boundaries were respected, even if she remained skeptical of the technology’s full potential.
